unnormalised: Delivery services in Bengaluru are facing a bit of a jam! Seems like a lot of packages are getting delayed 'cause of the crazy traffic and also, some confusion with addresses. Just got a heads-up from a friend whose parcel, meant for 221-B, Baker Street (okay, not really Baker Street, but you get the idea – some address in Koramangala 560034), went all the way to Whitefield, near Export Promotion Industrial Park (EPIP) Zone, Bangalore, 560066.
normalised: Delivery services in Bengaluru are facing a bit of a jam! Seems like a lot of packages are getting delayed because of the crazy traffic and also, some confusion with addresses. Just got a heads-up from a friend whose parcel, meant for two hundred and twenty one B, Baker Street (okay, not really Baker Street, but you get the idea – some address in Koramangala five hundred and sixty thousand and thirty four), went all the way to Whitefield, near Export Promotion Industrial Park (E-P-I-P) Zone, Bangalore, five hundred and sixty thousand and sixty six.

unnormalised: Apparently, a lot of delivery guys are relying solely on Google Maps, and sometimes, the pin drops in the wrong place or the address format on the app isn't super clear. Plus, you know how it is, many houses don't have proper name plates! Heard from a delivery executive that he had packages for "Near Axis Bank ATM, Indira Nagar" and another for "Opposite to the Big Bazaar, Malleswaram, pin code 560003". Good luck finding those!
normalised: Apparently, a lot of delivery guys are relying solely on Google Maps, and sometimes, the pin drops in the wrong place or the address format on the app isn't super clear. Plus, you know how it is, many houses don't have proper name plates! Heard from a delivery executive that he had packages for "Near Axis Bank A-T-M, Indira Nagar" and another for "Opposite to the Big Bazaar, Malleswaram, pin code five hundred and sixty thousand and three". Good luck finding those!

unnormalised: Folks are suggesting that courier companies should perhaps introduce a system where customers can add super specific details like "next to the blue gate" or "building number painted in green", or even their landmark's GPS coordinates, to the address. Could save a lot of headaches and time, right?
normalised: Folks are suggesting that courier companies should perhaps introduce a system where customers can add super specific details like "next to the blue gate" or "building number painted in green", or even their landmark's G-P-S coordinates, to the address. Could save a lot of headaches and time, right?
